qa_pairs.question: How does the Implied Repo Rate (IRR) formula relate to identifying the cheapest to deliver (CTD) bond in a futures contract, and what does a higher IRR indicate about a bond's position in the CTD ranking?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Implied Repo Rate (IRR) formula is used to identify the cheapest to deliver (CTD) bond in a futures contract by calculating the rate for each bond, with the highest IRR indicating the CTD.<cite>[S3]</cite></statement> <statement>A higher IRR indicates that a bond is more likely to be the cheapest to deliver because it has a lower initial value, leading to a higher return when delivered at the futures price.<cite>[S4]</cite></statement>

# Implied repo rate



**Implied repo rate** (**IRR**) is the rate of return of borrowing money to buy an asset in the spot market and delivering it in the futures market where the notional is used to repay the loan. [S2] ## Simplified closed form

{\displaystyle IRR=\left({\frac {\text{InvoicePrice}}{\text{PurchasePriceOfBond}}}-1\right)\left({\frac {\text{dayBase}}{\text{daysToDelivery}}}\right)}
where dayBase is 365 or 360


## Usage


### Determine the cheapest to deliver asset

To determine the cheapest bond in a basket of deliverable bonds against a futures contract, implied repo rate is computed for each bond; the bond with the highest repo rate is the cheapest. [S3] It is the cheapest because it has the lowest initial value to yield a higher return provided it is delivered with the stated futures price. [S4] The net basis between a futures price and its underlying bonds may provide an indication of which bond is the cheapest. [S5] However, since the method, unlike the IRR method, neglects the actual running cost of bonds, it is less accurate as a measure for CTD ranking.

qa_pairs.question: What is the relationship between the purchase price of a bond and its Implied Repo Rate (IRR), and how does this affect the bond's status as the cheapest to deliver (CTD)?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The purchase price of a bond is inversely related to its Implied Repo Rate (IRR). A lower purchase price increases the IRR, as the IRR formula [(InvoicePrice / PurchasePriceOfBond) − 1] × (dayBase / daysToDelivery) shows that the purchase price is in the denominator. This means higher IRRs are associated with bonds that have lower initial costs.<cite>[S2]</cite></statement><statement>The bond with the highest IRR is identified as the cheapest to deliver (CTD) because it offers the highest return on investment, assuming the futures price remains constant. This makes it cheaper to deliver due to its lower initial value, which yields a higher return when repaid at the futures price.<cite>[S3][S4]</cite></statement>
